semantic_title: Episodes When No Delivery Occurs - Principal Diagnosis Selection
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 15. Chapter 15: Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperium > b. Selection of OB Principal or First-listed Diagnosis > 3) Episodes when no delivery occurs

content.full_text: In episodes when no delivery occurs, the principal diagnosis should correspond to the principal complication of the pregnancy which necessitated the encounter. Should more than one complication exist, all of which are treated or monitored, any of the complication codes may be sequenced first. (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
content.summary: Guidelines for selecting principal diagnosis in pregnancy encounters without delivery (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
key_concepts: Principal complication identification (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
Multiple complication sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 65, L62)
Encounter necessity determination (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Principal diagnosis should be the principal complication necessitating encounter (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
detailed_rules.explanation: When no delivery occurs, select the main pregnancy complication that prompted the encounter as principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)

detailed_rules.rule_text: With multiple complications, any treated/monitored complication may be sequenced first (Evidence: pg no: 65, L62)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple complications are present and all are treated or monitored, any can be the principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 65, L62)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Confirm no delivery occurred during encounter
Step 2: Identify all pregnancy complications present
Step 3: Determine which complication necessitated the encounter
Step 4: If multiple complications treated/monitored, select any as principal

code_ranges.description: Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperium codes (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
code_ranges.requirement: Use for pregnancy complications without delivery
usage_rules: Principal complication as principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
Any treated complication can be first with multiple complications (Evidence: pg no: 65, L62)

references_to.title: When a delivery occurs
references_to.explanation: Contrasts with delivery encounter coding guidelines

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted for severe preeclampsia at 34 weeks, managed conservatively, discharged without delivery
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: 34-week gestation, admitted for severe preeclampsia with proteinuria, managed with bed rest and monitoring, discharged home without delivery
step_by_step: Step 2: Identify severe preeclampsia as principal complication
Step 3: Assign O14.13 as principal diagnosis

correct_coding.rationale: Severe preeclampsia was the principal complication necessitating admission (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should use specific complication code, not supervision code
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using supervision codes instead of specific complication codes

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with gestational diabetes and mild preeclampsia, both conditions monitored during admission
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: 32-week gestation, admitted for management of gestational diabetes and mild preeclampsia, both conditions monitored and treated
step_by_step: Step 2: Identify both gestational diabetes and preeclampsia as treated complications
Step 3: Either complication can be sequenced as principal diagnosis

correct_coding.rationale: Multiple complications treated allows any to be sequenced first (Evidence: pg no: 65, L62)

incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Trying to determine single 'most important' complication when multiple are treated

warnings: Only applies to encounters where no delivery occurs (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61)
best_practices: Identify the complication that necessitated the encounter (Evidence: pg no: 65, L61-L62)
Document all complications that are treated or monitored
common_mistakes: Using supervision codes instead of specific complication codes
Difficulty selecting principal diagnosis with multiple complications
tips: Focus on why the patient sought care or was admitted
With multiple complications, any treated condition can be principal
implementation_notes: Requires clinical judgment to identify principal complication
